qas.question: Which two Asian countries have started to adopt the rule of law?
What has influenced China and Vietnam to conform to the rule of law?

answers.text: the transition to a market economy

qas.question: Who is debating the reliance on the rule of law in China?
To whom is the rule of law important to in China's trade deals?
What values might adherence to the rule of law subsequently influence in China?
What type of economy has rule of law help China and Vietnam move towards?

plausible_answers.text: foreign investors and to economic development

qas.question: What is rule of law not important for?
What has already spilled over to other areas in China and Vietnam?
What two Asian countries have refused to adopt the rule of law?

context: In countries such as <a0_0><b8_0>China and Vietnam<b8_0/><a0_0/>, <a1_0>the transition to a <b5_0>market economy<b5_0/><a1_0/> has been a major factor in a move toward the rule of law, because a rule of law is important to <a3_0><b6_0>foreign investors<a3_0/> and to economic development<b6_0/>. It remains unclear whether <b7_0>the rule of law<b7_0/> in countries like China and Vietnam will be limited to commercial matters or will spill into other areas as well, and if so whether that spillover will enhance prospects for related values such as <a4_0>democracy and human rights<a4_0/>. The rule of law in China has been widely discussed and debated by both <a2_0>legal scholars and politicians<a2_0/> in China.
